channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: The world’s largest contract chip maker is considering building a semiconductor factory in Singapore to help address a global supply shortage https://t.co/SPCUCETBkg
Here is an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal's weekend edition https://t.co/LN1qpRpP25 https://t.co/9edphX94kW
Boeing Starliner spacecraft successfully docked with the International Space Station, an important milestone on a test mission where the vehicle faced some technical issues. https://t.co/vhPZxcQ1ND
The Lincoln Memorial, dedicated 100 years ago this month, took time to grow into one of America’s most important national symbols. https://t.co/ThkPX4IG6q
More business schools are venturing into virtual reality, using video delivered via headsets to immerse students in far-flung locales https://t.co/8s6pgskLds
Old Navy made a big bet on inclusive sizes; it backfired. The chain ended up with too many XS and XL clothes, and too few of the rest. https://t.co/aVqvAU8BK2

The two sons of former Panama President Ricardo Martinelli were sentenced to three years in prison on Friday for their role in a bribery scheme involving the Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht https://t.co/kQIcWHCJM6

The stock market selloff has been bad news for most investors, but not for Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway. Here’s what his company has been spending billions on. #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/GaRe19hrdP https://t.co/PrRqAdv4FG
SpaceX Chief Executive Elon Musk pledged to install satellites over the Amazon, connecting more schools to the internet and improving monitoring of illegal rainforest logging https://t.co/IFDIs2C2Fx
Breaking: A late-day rally helped the S&P 500 avoid entering a bear market. The Dow still posted its eighth straight weekly loss, the longest streak since 1932. https://t.co/LakZlWDhXN

Wells Fargo Advisors, a brokerage arm of the bank, has agreed to pay $7 million in a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission after alleged glitches in a new anti-money-laundering system let suspicious transactions escape initial notice https://t.co/5LerBMu2C0

Hillary Clinton approved of an effort in 2016 to provide the press with research purporting to show a computer link between Trump's company and a Russian bank, her campaign manager Robby Mook testified https://t.co/NzwmqiYbFE

Long lines formed at a McDonald’s restaurant in Moscow after the company announced it will leave Russia over its invasion of Ukraine. It ends more than three decades of business in Russia. #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/x2juYNWyj6 https://t.co/JsWVD39e4X

Breaking: A federal judge blocked the Biden administration from ending Title 42, a controversial pandemic-era border policy that prevents migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border from asking for asylum https://t.co/pp951xE1yt

House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who is a practicing Catholic, may not receive Communion in her San Francisco archdiocese because of her support for abortion rights, the city’s archbishop said https://t.co/NyCZ0ukU7f

Ukraine’s military intelligence chief said the country would keep fighting until it evicts Russian forces from all of its territory—including Crimea and other areas effectively seized by Moscow in 2014 https://t.co/JzwErko3iV
From @WSJopinion: Fixing the baby formula shortage requires fixing the government policies that helped to create it https://t.co/PMrgXCpLMa
A private collector purchased a rare 1955 Mercedes-Benz for $142 million, making it the most expensive car ever sold at auction https://t.co/W040cAQqNi

The Senate approved a nearly $40 billion military and economic aid package to help Ukraine repel Russia’s invasion, bringing America’s total commitment to almost $54 billion #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/nzN4WS1TJv https://t.co/BdjpRoDtI9
The U.S. Secret Service said it was sending home two employees who were in Seoul for President Biden’s Asia trip after an alleged altercation with a local resident https://t.co/lJxpu2KfsL
A monkeypox outbreak first detected in the U.K. has been reported in several countries, including the U.S. and Canada. Here's what you need to know about the disease. https://t.co/q45cPVDqIY
What did Warner Bros. Discovery's new CEO do in his first month in charge? Killed CNN+, questioned a Clint Eastwood movie, laid off much of the key leadership. https://t.co/6Eq3J5PVqZ
Worried about price gouging in oil and gas? Take a look at babysitting. https://t.co/mlSOaj83nv

Ukraine’s military intelligence chief said the country would keep fighting until it evicts Russian forces from all of its territory—including Crimea and other areas effectively seized by Moscow in 2014 https://t.co/TQTkYBvUpX
Canada will ban equipment made by China’s Huawei and ZTE from being used in its 5G mobile network, following a nearly four-year security review https://t.co/sFVJa3dMz2
Companies are putting up with poor performers in a tight labor market because there’s no guarantee of finding someone better https://t.co/cfCSpv9lMw

When the FBI’s general counsel received information in September 2016 from a national-security lawyer, Michael Sussmann, that possibly tied the Trump campaign to Russia, it set off alarms at the agency, he testified Thursday https://t.co/WRVK12LvnE
A Chinese Communist Party directive bars senior officials from owning property abroad or stakes in overseas entities, whether directly or through spouses and children https://t.co/60QTMPY8TO

As Russian setbacks in Ukraine have mounted, critical voices have grown louder. One retired colonel, appearing on state TV, cautioned viewers that “the situation will clearly get worse for us.” https://t.co/c8XTGGsIC6
Canada is banning the use of 5G equipment from China’s Huawei and ZTE https://t.co/TYPyO9D3n6
Essay: There’s an overlooked reason why women leave jobs and are stymied in their careers: More than men, they get saddled with work that isn’t valued. https://t.co/sBXLSEDZtP

Elon Musk’s recent tweets cast doubt on whether the billionaire will follow through with his agreement to buy Twitter for $44 billion. Twitter, meanwhile, can try to force him to follow through. This flowchart illustrates how the deal could play out. https://t.co/JWfkS48NIh
Canada will ban equipment made by China’s Huawei and ZTE from being used in the country’s next-generation 5G mobile network, according to a person familiar with the matter https://t.co/Z1Nbh24fOt

From @WSJopinion: Every member of NATO has enthusiastically welcomed Finland and Sweden except one. This should raise the question of whether Turkey under Erdogan’s leadership belongs in the alliance, write Joe Lieberman and Mark D. Wallace https://t.co/10kmqm6oOc

Consumers with low credit scores are falling behind on payments for car loans, personal loans and credit cards, a sign that the healthiest consumer lending environment on record in the U.S. is coming to an end https://t.co/DalSnP65Z3

Russia dismissed calls from top United Nations and Western officials to halt a Black Sea blockade that has prevented Ukraine from exporting much of its grain to world markets, causing price hikes and exacerbating food shortages https://t.co/p7kDHWkJ64

A judge’s financial disclosure could potentially cause a new headache for the Justice Department in its decadelong effort to extradite and convict Kim Dotcom, founder of the file-sharing service Megaupload https://t.co/Kadwu6iSSr
Breaking: Oklahoma’s legislature passed another near-total abortion ban, one that extends its Texas-style enforcement to any stage of pregnancy https://t.co/ZKN05Ou0vD

Gas prices hit a record of $4.59 a gallon Thursday, the highest national average recorded by AAA since they began tracking fuel costs in 2000. The pain at the pump is expected to get worse as the summer travel season begins. https://t.co/C4sFgnCLmN
Filmmaker Anthony Russo speaks with @erichschwartzel at the #WSJFuture of Everything Festival https://t.co/G3PUz76suj
A $40 billion Ukraine aid package passed the Senate with bipartisan support. It now goes to President Biden and takes America's commitment to almost $54 billion. https://t.co/980khtETEG
Planned Parenthood CEO Alexis McGill Johnson says that the White House has been working behind the scenes to help ensure abortion access. #WSJFuture https://t.co/hIjuq4XKtD https://t.co/VveCcZ5wUz

During the occupation of Dymer, north of Kyiv, the Russian-appointed mayor tried to persuade locals to support Moscow. He was left behind as the Russians abruptly withdrew, and now faces charges of collaboration. https://t.co/Tfu9QTuVqb

U.S. Men’s National Soccer Team Coach Gregg Berhalter hailed the new labor deal equalizing pay structures for the men’s and women’s teams as a global marker for sports. #WSJFuture https://t.co/bEQpiiVqGC https://t.co/m91Xv9JPyj
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/z4enGBNrsB https://t.co/EgkQjWU3b9

Borrowers with low credit scores are defaulting on payments for car loans, personal loans and credit cards, a sign that the healthiest consumer lending environment on record is coming to an end #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/SaU7YJFrtw https://t.co/CyonGA3n3f
President Biden invoked the Defense Production Act to increase baby formula supply amid a growing shortage #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/5kH9Yd1VOF https://t.co/0dGDB168fd
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/y88mQnWsrf https://t.co/tccpJZnasq
Martin Shkreli, the so-called “pharma bro” who was widely criticized for raising the price of a lifesaving AIDS drug, has been released from federal prison https://t.co/LjW1oaIvok
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/6gJDzXAxEy https://t.co/rC9K3QleYt
